headline: YouTube to stream NBA games live in India
content:
The National Basketball Association (NBA) has announced an expansion of its content partnership with YouTube, bringing live
NBA
games and marquee events to fans in India via the league’s global YouTube channel for the remainder of the 2024-25 season.
The livestreams will feature weekly regular-season matchups, NBA All-Star 2025, select NBA Playoff games, and the 2025 NBA Finals presented by YouTube TV.
To further enhance the viewing experience, the NBA will collaborate with leading YouTube creators to livestream select games and events on their channels. The initiative kicks off with the popular creator duo Jordindian streaming the State Farm All-Star Saturday Night on Sunday, February 16, at 7 am IST.
“Expanding our collaboration with YouTube to livestream NBA games and events in India reflects our commitment to making the excitement of NBA basketball more accessible to the millions of fans across the country,” said NBA India Business Head of Global Partnerships and Media Sunny Malik.
“YouTube’s significant reach and innovative, localised offerings will help us better engage fans nationwide and deepen their connection with their favorite NBA teams and players.”

headline: Vicky Kaushal's 'Chhaava' earns Rs 50 crore at worldwide box office on opening day
content:
Vicky Kaushal
's historical action film "
Chhaava
" collected Rs 50 crore at the box office worldwide on day one, the makers said on Saturday. Directed by Laxman Utekar, the film is produced by Dinesh Vijan under his banner
Maddock Films
.
The movie, which also stars
Rashmika Mandanna
and
Akshaye Khanna
, was released in theatres on Friday.
The production banner shared the numbers of "Chhaava" on its official X handle on Saturday and said the movie has set the record of the "biggest opening ever for a
historical Hindi film
."
"Yeh 'Chhaava ki dahaad' hai. Roared like a true warrior king! Biggest opening ever for a Historical Hindi Film. Book your tickets now," the studio wrote along with a poster, which mentioned that the movie collected Rs 50 crore gross globally on the opening day.
According to the makers, the film earned Rs 33.1 crore net at the domestic box office.
Live Events
"Chhaava" marks the third biographical film for Kaushal after "Sardar Udham" and "Sam Bahadur".
In the movie, Kaushal essays the role of Maratha emperor
Chhatrapati Sambhaji Maharaj
, who was the son of Maratha empire founder Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj.
Mandanna plays Sambhaji Maharaj's wife Maharani Yesubai and Khanna stars as Aurangzeb. The cast also includes Diana Penty, Ashutosh Rana and Vineet Kumar Singh.

Lenskart
has purchased the Delhi franchise for Season 2 of the
Global e-Cricket Premier League
(GEPL) from

, a company in digital entertainment and technology.
GEPL, the world’s largest e-cricket and entertainment league, is played on JetSynthesys’ flagship mobile gaming app, Real Cricket, which has amassed over 300 million lifetime downloads.
The league has experienced a fivefold surge in player interest—910,000 compared to Season 1—highlighting its immense growth potential among digital screen users.
The inaugural season attracted over 200,000 registrations, culminating in the selection of 48 elite players across eight teams. With a staggering multiplatform reach of over 70 million and more than 2.4 million minutes of streamed content on JioCinema and Sports18, GEPL has quickly established itself as a trailblazer in cricket esports.
Previously, JetSynthesys secured franchise owners for the Bengaluru and Chennai franchises.

headline: Tata Group unit broadcasts 80% of global sporting events
content:
Tata Communications Ltd
. is now responsible for recording and broadcasting 80% of the world’s
sporting events
thanks to the 2022 acquisition of a US-based live production and video transmission firm, a top executive said.
The acquisition of
Switch Enterprises
LLC three years ago has contributed to Tata generating content for events such as Formula 1, World Rally Championship, DP World Tour, the South Korean league and Sail GP, the company’s Vice-President and Global Media head Dhaval Ponda said in an interview.
“We are largely becoming a virtual stadium of the world,” Ponda said, adding that sporting content the
Tata Group
unit generates reaches an audience of two billion people.
Ponda said the company has delivered 100,000 plus events and 15,000 plus hours of edge streaming in 190 plus countries. Those statistics, in other words, mean that a bulk of the content being streamed live is likely enabled by Tata Communications.
The global
live streaming
market is expected to grow to around $712.9 billion by 2033 from an estimated $104.9 billion in 2024, according to research and advisory firm Custom Market Insights. While the number takes into account all video and audio transferred in real-time including over social media, Tata Communication’s business concerns only the back-end content production for networks that already own broadcasting rights for events.
Live Events
Ponda declined to offer guidance on financial targets for the media vertical, but said he’s “confident of continuing to be a high growth business for Tata Communications’ digital portfolio.”
The Switch acquisition helped the company open a new production and delivery facility in Los Angeles to support growing global live content customers, he said. Tata Communications has also expanded its portfolio to cover everything from concerts to cricket and rugby world cups to college and post-college sports, news events, and the Oscars, he added.

headline: Indian sports tech industry to touch Rs 49,500 crore market size by FY29
content:
India’s
sports technology
market is on a rapid growth trajectory, with projections indicating it will reach Rs 49,500 crore by FY29, growing at a Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of 13%.
This forecast comes from a report released by Deloitte India in collaboration with the Federation of Indian
Fantasy Sports
(
FIFS
). The report highlights the sector’s significant contributions to fan engagement, data analytics, and employment, underscoring its critical role in India’s sporting ecosystem.
The sports technology market in India is already a robust industry, valued at Rs 26,700 crore in FY24. The fan engagement sector dominates the market, contributing Rs 21,400 crore, while the data and analytics segment accounts for Rs 5,300 crore.
Over the past five years (FY18–FY23), cumulative investments in the sector have reached Rs 27,500 crore.
Fantasy Sports Platforms (FSPs) have emerged as a major driver of growth within the sports technology market. In FY24 alone, FSPs generated Rs 9,100 crore in revenue, with an additional Rs 8,300 crore in indirect revenue.

GST
, including retrospective taxation, have impacted the fantasy sports industry, leading to a dip in projected revenue to Rs 8,190 crore in FY25. However, the growth may bounce back next year and touch Rs 9,420 crore, reaching Rs 10,550 crore by FY26.
The sports technology industry has become a key employment generator, creating 12,000 direct and indirect jobs in FY23. As the sector continues to expand, this number is expected to grow, further bolstering India’s economy.
The esports market in India is projected to reach Rs 1,286 crore by 2029, growing at a 25% CAGR from 2024 to 2029. Similarly, the game developers' market is expected to hit Rs 875 crore by 2029, with a CAGR of 27% during the same period (2024–2029).
Prashanth Rao, Partner at Deloitte India, noted the interconnectedness of the sports technology ecosystem with the broader sports industry. “The sports technology ecosystem is closely linked to the broader sports industry in India, which itself requires significant investment and support,” he said,
Rao noted that India's
sports tech
market is currently 1% of the global market, with significant growth potential compared to North America (34%) and APAC (30%).
Joy Bhattacharjya, Director-General of FIFS, echoed this sentiment, stating, “The entire sports tech sector is not just important, it’s vital for India’s sporting development.”
Bhattacharjya highlighted that technology is a major enabler, with advancements in AI, ML, AR/VR, and data analytics driving fan engagement and athlete performance, while Rao stated that fantasy sports have transformed fans from passive viewers to active participants.
Bhattacharjya said that the FSP industry is seeking clearer regulations, especially around distinguishing between games of skill and chance, and preventing capital flight to foreign countries. Retrospective taxation and lack of a stable policy regime are creating uncertainty for the FSPs, he added.
"The industry is not shying away from regulation but is seeking clarity and stability in policies to foster growth and prevent capital flight. We also want the debate over games of skill vs. games of chance to be settled once and for all," Bhattacharjya said.

headline: Valentine's Day special: 7 best romantic movies to watch with your partner
Block bookings are on the rise as many films end as horror shows
content:
Block booking
of
movie tickets
by producers and stars has resurfaced as a major concern in the
film trade
, with its impact on opening collections of recent Hindi and pan-India films drawing scrutiny.
Industry insiders highlight two key issues in this growing trend: the scale of block bookings and their link to a film’s quality.
The practice pushes up first-weekend numbers, creating an illusion of success.
Among recent films, the multilingual Game Changer saw a higher share of block bookings than organic audience ticket purchases. According to data from box office tracking firm Sacnilk, out of Rs 2.5 crore in advance bookings, Rs 1.5 crore came from block bookings. However, the film failed to sustain momentum and grossed approximately Rs 155 crore on a budget of Rs 400-450 crore.
Veteran trade analyst Komal Nahta noted, “In the past, block booking was like salt in a well-cooked dish—never too much or too little, just adequate. However, for a recent film, the producers block-booked tickets worth Rs 40 crore (net collections) out of Rs 80 crore the film collected in a week's time. This shows how excessive block booking has become.”
Live Events
Analysts say that when block bookings outpace organic
audience demand
, films often struggle at the box office. A higher reliance on block bookings, trade experts note, also signals weaker content and poor long-term performance.
"Audiences cannot be hoodwinked. If a viewer books a ticket and finds 90% of the auditorium empty, the film is doomed through word-of-mouth," Nahta added.
Block booking occurs in several ways. Producers buy tickets in bulk for their affiliates. Corporations—especially brands associated with film stars—purchase tickets as part of endorsement deals, with ticket values often counted as part of a star’s remuneration. Additionally, producers barter tickets in exchange for services.
A producer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said, “Producers typically set aside 2-10% of a film’s budget for block booking after gauging the response to its trailer. They consider this a marketing expense.”
Trade analysts argue that block booking is often used when producers lack confidence in their films’ ability to attract audiences. By artificially inflating opening weekend figures, they aim to negotiate better deals with streaming platforms.
Movie trade analyst Girish Wankhede remarked, “Allocating a film’s budget to boost its first three-day collection is a recent phenomenon, but it’s not an honest approach. The aim is clear—producers inflate box office numbers to secure higher prices for digital and satellite rights.”
A recent box office forecast by media and entertainment research firm Ormax Media found that corporate bookings do not translate into sustained footfalls. Initial spikes in collections fail to hold if the film does not meet audience expectations.
Ameya Naik, producer and founder of Fantasy Films, said, “If a film’s trailer is well received, audience footfalls will grow organically. Block booking reflects a lack of confidence in one’s own creation. And audiences are smart enough to recognise this tactic."

headline: Sony-backed Toonsutra raises $3.2 million seed financing led by Holtzbrinck Publishing Group
content:
Sony Innovation Fund-backes
Toonsutra
, India’s leading
comic app
, has said that it has closed a new Seed Round of $3.2 million in financing from a group of investors.
The round was led by German media company
Holtzbrinck Publishing Group
, who is dedicated to the progress of science, education, and the culture of reading through companies like Macmillan Publishers and Springer Nature, while also investing in technology businesses.
In addition to Holtzbrinck, the round included venture funds GMJP, T-Accelerate, and Google. Graphic India, the country’s comic and animation creator, also participated in the round.
Toonsutra’s
webtoon
comic app has established itself as the top comic app in India in both the Apple and Android stores for over 10 months with over 2 million downloads to date.
The company is founded by Sharad Devarajan and Vishal Anand, who bring expertise in building
Indian startups
and creating entertainment experiences across comics, animation, and digital media platforms.
Live Events
"I have long admired Holtzbrinck’s and Google’s entrepreneurial spirit and commitment to creators across various media formats. We are honored to have them and this group of investors as we continue to build on our mission to shape India’s webtoon and comic fandom," commented Toonsutra Co-Founder & CEO, Vishal Anand. “At Toonsutra we are creating an ecosystem where the biggest global creators and publishers can thrive by reaching regional language audiences, and Indian readers can discover new worlds with every scroll. Our mission goes beyond entertainment – we're fostering a new era of creativity, community and creative expression in India."
Filmon Zerai, COO of Holtzbrinck Publishing Group, added, "Toonsutra represents an exciting confluence of digital innovation and cultural resonance in one of the world's markets. Their growth and leadership position in India's mobile comic space demonstrates the team's understanding of both content and technology. At Holtzbrinck, we recognize the potential of the webtoon format and believe Toonsutra is uniquely positioned to capitalize on India's youth audience. We look forward to supporting Vishal, Sharad, and the team as they continue to build India's digital comics platform."
Toonsutra’s mission is to bring together a community of fandom and pop-culture, catering to India’s 700 million+ mobile youth market.
The webtoon comics app caters to Indian audiences with Hindi, Tamil, and Telugu language content offerings. The company has partnered with publishers to bring over 3100+ titles and 500,000+ episodes, spanning global hits and domestic originals.
“With over two million downloads and growing, Toonsutra has shown that Indian audiences are ready to embrace a new era of digital fandom and storytelling. As a lifelong comic book fan and creator, I’m thrilled to bring the best comics and webtoons from around the world into India’s local languages for the very first time. This is an incredible opportunity to introduce millions across the country to the transformative power of this medium while inspiring a new generation of Indian comic and webtoon creators to share their stories and redefine global pop culture.” commented Toonsutra Co-Founder & Chairman, Sharad Devarajan.
The webtoon market is projected to reach $130 billion by some estimates, making it one of the categories for media and content.
Previous investors in Toonsutra include
Sony Innovation Fund
, Maiora Capital, and startup veterans, Gen Fukunaga (Founder, Funimation); Kun Gao (Co-Founder, Crunchyroll); Jeremy Liew (partner, Lightspeed); Kevin Lin (Co-Founder, Twitch); Patrick Lee (Co-Founder, Rotten Tomatoes); Keisuke Honda (KSK Angel Fund); Holly Lui (Co-Founder, Kabam); Benjamin Grubbs (Co-Founder, CreatorPlus); Steve Chung (fmr. CEO of Americas, CJENM); and others.

headline: From 'Chhaava' to 'Loveyapa': Bollywood films hitting screens this February
Bollywood's northeast blindspot: A filmmaker's take with Jahnu Barua
content:
In the early 1970s, Shillong became the stage for an unexpected flashpoint when a Bollywood movie laced with stereotypes ignited the fury of Naga students. Ye Gulistan Hamara, a Hindi film starring Dev Anand and Sharmila Tagore, revolved around a tribal community in the Northeast. But something cut deep. The Nagas found the song, “Mera Naam Aao”, and its picturisation a crude and offensive misrepresentation of their Ao brethren. Outraged, the students vandalised a movie hall, forcing the Meghalaya police to crack down with lathis. Several student protesters later found their way into the ranks of Naga insurgents, with one of them, VS Atem, becoming a top commander of the National Socialist Council of Nagalim (NSCN-IM).
Bollywood has long played fast and loose with the sensitivities of the Northeast, a region rich in linguistic and ethnic diversity. So when the second season of
Paatal Lok
dropped last month—featuring characters speaking Nagamese, the lingua franca of Nagaland, and capturing the state’s turmoil with rare nuance—it came as a refreshing surprise to those familiar with the region. Among the unexpected highlights was the presence of award-winning
Assamese filmmaker Jahnu Barua
, 72, who stepped in front of the camera to play Uncle Ken, a former rebel leader torn between his past and his vision of peace and prosperity for the troubled state. In an interview with Shantanu Nandan Sharma, the Mumbai-based director shares his thoughts on Bollywood’s portrayal of the Northeast and what led him to step out from behind the camera and into the spotlight. Edited excerpts:
You rarely step in front of the camera. What made you act in
Paatal Lok
, Season 2?
I acted in school plays a long time ago. But ever since I became a filmmaker, acting was never on my agenda. However, my close friends have known for decades that I have a knack for mimicking characters. Once Basu Chatterjee offered me the role of a Japanese astrologer in the television serial
Kakaji Kahin
(1988), and I obliged. Several fellow filmmakers have approached me with acting roles, usually for characters with a northeastern look, but I invariably declined. Often, such characters are introduced merely for comic relief, and I don’t appreciate that approach.
When the writer of
Paatal Lok 2
narrated the script to me, I felt the story was genuine and presented the Northeast with authenticity. The writer, Sudip Sharma, grew up in Guwahati and, more importantly, understands the sensitivities of the region. That convinced me to accept the role.
Live Events
Is acting a challenge for a director?
For a filmmaker, acting in a film is a beautiful experience, it brings a realisation. It is easy to shout at actors from behind the camera, but once you step in front of it, you truly understand the difficulties actors face. Playing Uncle Ken was particularly difficult. He is physically worn out, battling terminal kidney cancer, yet remains mentally strong. I was given a walking stick, but I had to portray a character with a strong mind.
What’s your take on the portrayal of Northeast India in mainstream Hindi movies?
It’s a two-fold issue: how the rest of India perceives the Northeast and how the Northeast views the mainstream, particularly cinema. For many filmmakers, the Northeast feels like an alien region, as though it is from another planet. Hindi cinema, driven by commercial interests, often overlooks themes or characters from distant regions because the market dynamics don’t demand it. This is a misguided perception, but that’s how films are made.
Is that the only reason we hardly see Northeast faces in Bollywood? Are language and accent a barrier?
Language and accent are not a problem at all. In the realm of visual arts, audiences often embrace diversity in language and accent—it’s seen as something beautiful. The real issue, I feel, is that many young talents from the Northeast, though full of dreams and talent, lack the aggression required to enter and survive in Bollywood. Danny Denzongpa (an actor from Sikkim) is an exception. Despite many obstacles, he carved a niche in popular Hindi cinema. The challenges are clear: most people from the Northeast have distinct physical features, which lead to discrimination. However, we must recognise that discrimination can happen anywhere in the world.
As someone from the region, does it hurt you?
Yes, it hurts. I recall popular actors and filmmakers asking me, ‘Is it safe to travel to the Northeast?’ That kind of ignorance hurts me. For decades, the perception was that we lived in jungles. But I don’t want to solely blame filmmakers. The entire system is at fault.
What do you mean by the fault of the system?
To a large extent, political leaders—particularly from Assam and the Northeast—have allowed such ignorance to seep into society. For many decades, Indian history textbooks didn’t even include a chapter on the Northeast. Did our own leaders address this with the Central government? No. The Northeast has a rich, vibrant history. When society is ignorant about a region, it manifests everywhere, including in Bollywood. The Northeast may have been politically integrated into India, but social integration is still far from complete.
Why is Bollywood reluctant to explore the Northeast as a destination for film shoots, even though the insurgency has receded?
I believe there should be more films and series that feature Northeast themes and actors. The state governments in the region should encourage such initiatives.

headline: Racing Ahead To Revolutionise Industries
content:
The latest episode of Meet the Drapers in London showcased innovative ideas, featuring entrepreneurs seeking to transform AI, fintech, and mental health
Peter Szalontay Co-Founder & CEO, Lazy AI
The stage was set for an exciting display of innovation and entrepreneurial brilliance as Meet the Drapers brought together remarkable startups from across the globe. The venue this time was London. Tim Draper was joined by an impressive panel of jury members, including Harry Yeh, the driving force behind Quantum Fintech, Natalia Vodianova, the visionary Co-Founder of Locals.org, and Lord Aamer Sarfraz, a prominent member of the UK House of Lords. Together, they evaluated groundbreaking ideas ranging from game-changing AI tools to revolutionary solutions in mental health. Each pitch wasn’t just about business—it was about reimagining the future. The first presenter, Sumit Kishore, Founder of ActaLink, introduced a smart wallet powered by account abstraction. Designed to seamlessly bridge Web2 and Web3 payment systems, the wallet allows programmable automation of digital transactions. Sumit spoke about how this innovation could make Web3 payments as intuitive as using a traditional credit card. Peter Szalontay and Misha Lyalin, the brains behind Lazy AI, showcased their AI-powered platform that democratises software creation. With over 30,000 users already in their community, their goal is to make developing software as simple as writing text in natural language. By lowering costs and eliminating technical barriers, Lazy AI is positioned to transform industries reliant on rapid software development. Martin van der Heijden and José Martin Quesada (JJ), founders of Krew.build, pitched their AI co-pilot for private equity teams. Their tool streamlines data analysis and automates repetitive tasks, providing firms with more time to focus on strategic decision-making.
Misha Lyalin Co-Founder & CTO, Lazy AI
The duo highlighted how Krew.build could reduce operational bottlenecks in a sector traditionally dependent on manual processes. Soula Care, co-founded by Olga Ivanova, presented the company’s powerful mission to help women tackle mental health challenges. Ivanova, drawing from her own experience with burnout, created Soula Care to offer AI-driven support that’s not just about managing stress, but also about empowering women to build resilience and confidence. The platform is designed with a deep understanding of women’s needs, offering compassionate, personalised assistance. The jury had a tough decision, evaluating startups based on their market potential, execution, and the real-world problems they aimed to solve. While each company brought a unique vision, Lazy AI stood out for its ability to make software development more accessible through natural language. Its rapid adoption and strong community engagement highlighted its potential to reshape the industry, ultimately securing it a spot in the next stage. Peter Szalontay, co-founder & CEO of Lazy AI, said, “Imagine if a tool could drastically decrease costs while making development more accessible. Lazy AI empowers everyone to create software using our most innate skill—natural language.” Meet the Drapers continues to be a platform for innovators, offering them a stage to inspire and bring their vision to life.

headline: Pushpa-2's record-smashing box office performance gives PVR Inox big profit boost in Q3
content:
PVR Inox
has reported an exceptional financial performance in the third quarter of FY 2024, largely driven by the unprecedented success of Pushpa 2. The film’s record-breaking box office numbers helped the multiplex giant achieve its highest earnings of the year.
Pushpa 2 not only smashed records but also contributed significantly to the company’s overall growth, making history as the biggest blockbuster ever in Indian cinema. The film accounted for a staggering 36% of PVR Inox's Q3 India box office collections and 12% of the overall India box office for CY 2024.
In December alone, Pushpa 2 grossed over Rs 1,450 crores in India, with its Hindi-dubbed version contributing a significant Rs 900 crores, setting a new benchmark as the
highest-grossing Hindi film
ever. The blockbuster's performance lifted the entire box office, despite challenges presented by the rescheduling of key films and other underperforming releases earlier in the quarter.
While Pushpa 2 undoubtedly stole the spotlight, regional cinema also played a crucial role in PVR Inox's strong Q3 performance. The continued success of South Indian films was evident in the quarter’s box office results, especially with hits like Devara Part-1 and Vettaiyan, which dominated October’s earnings. Their strong performance reflected the growing reach and popularity of Tamil and Telugu films beyond their traditional audiences.
Even mid-budget regional films saw success, with Lucky Baskhar earning around Rs 90 crores and the Tamil film Amaran surpassing Rs 250 crores, cementing its place as the second highest-grossing Tamil film of the year.
Live Events
In contrast, Bollywood struggled during the quarter, with Hindi and English films such as Jigra and Joker 2 failing to meet expectations.
Despite this, PVR Inox’s strong regional offerings and the spectacular success of Pushpa 2 provided the much-needed lift to the company's overall performance for the third quarter of fiscal year 2024.
Commenting on the results, Mr. Ajay Kumar Bijli, Managing Director of PVR Inox, said, "As we look ahead, our focus remains on pivoting to the capital light model, enhancing free cash generation, reducing net debt, controlling costs, and delivering a diverse slate of films that excite and inspire moviegoers. With a robust content pipeline, a slew of strategic growth initiatives, and continued financial discipline, we are confident in sustaining our leadership and driving long-term value for all stakeholders."

headline: Are South Indian films really the game changer they've been made out to be?
content:
Recent box office failures of high-budget southern films, such as Game Changer (Telugu), UI (Kannada), and Kanguva (Tamil), have put the belief to test that dubbed versions of regional films perennially dominate the Hindi film market. Producers and analysts are reassessing the narrative that southern cinema is consistently outpacing
Bollywood
. Industry watchers are now asking a critical question: Is regional cinema truly performing as well as perceived?
Key criteria such as
box office collections
, and footfalls, which capture the economics of films show that regional films--especially southern films--are not performing as good as Hindi audiences perceive them to do.
According to media and entertainment research firm Ormax Media’s Box Office Report: 2024, the performance of southern films is not significantly different from Hindi films. Box office collections of Tamil and
Kannada films
in 2024 have declined by 3-7% compared to 2023.
Meanwhile, Telugu films—often perceived as dominating the Hindi market through dubbed versions—have recorded only a modest 3.5% growth in collections.
Veteran filmmaker Vipul Amrutlal Shah, known for hits like Aankhen (2002) and Singh Is Kinng (2008), said, "People focus on a limited number of southern hits and assume most are doing well. Ultimately, a film's story has to work, whether in its original language or dubbed."
Live Events
Blockbusters? Hardly
Among southern films, select
Telugu films
dubbed in Hindi have managed to break out of their home markets and perform well in the Hindi film industry. However, in their home states, their success has relied more on ticket price hikes than audience turnout.
According to Ormax Media data, domestic footfalls for Telugu films have dropped by 13.6% to 21.3 crore in 2024, compared to 2023.
Tanuj Garg, managing partner, Ellipsis Entertainment, a production house, said, "While I am hugely appreciative of Telugu cinema and their vision, conviction and scale, I think the media and trade circuit get carried away in claiming that they are ruling the Hindi film industry." He added: "The few dubbed Telugu films which have worked are an exception rather than a rule. What we in the rest of India never get to hear about is the ones that didn't work. This tendency to generalise and form trends is dangerous."
Recently, a pan-India attempt Telugu Game Changer which is estimated to be made in the budget of Rs400-450 crore did not perform well at the box office as it has collected less than Rs150 crore since its release three weeks ago.
Ameya Naik, a producer and founder-Fantasy Films--an event management company, said, "Selective and few successes of southern films which cross over their home states mask failures of a sufficiently large number of southern films in their home states." The producer added, "Even down the South, makers are facing similar challenges in terms of stars increasing their remuneration. What differentiates the southern market from Hindi is the loyalty of its audiences and daredevil and hands-on producers who work collaboratively based on their skills and competencies."
In the southern markets, Malayalam films have been an exception. According to Ormax Media, box office collection of Malayalam films has grown by 104% to Rs1165 crore in 2024 compared to 2023. A producer who requested anonymity said, "Unlike Kannada films, which are not working due to emergence of a cosmopolitan culture in Bangalore, Malayalam films which hardly cross over Kerala and are rooted in their culture are performing well in the state." He added, "In 2024, there were nine blockbusters in the Malayalam film industry compared to five in 2023."
Increasingly, a key aspect which southern films share with Hindi films is the large contribution of their top ten films to their collections.

Mukta A2 Cinemas opens two-screen multiplex in central Mumbai's Kalyan
content:
Mukta A2 Cinemas
opens new property in Kalyan (central Mumbai) as part of its ongoing strategic expansion. This new 2-screen cinema marks a significant milestone in the brand’s vision to grow its screen count across India in 2025-2026, making moviegoing more accessible to audiences nationwide. This property will take the company's total screen capacity to 70.
Located in a prime area of Kalyan, a suburb in the central part of Mumbai, the new cinema combines cutting-edge technology with an elevated guest experience. The venue offers luxurious seating with sofas and recliners, ensuring comfort that’s second to none. Moviegoers will enjoy crystal-clear images thanks to the 2K Laser projectors, while Dolby surround sound and 3D capabilities enhance the immersive viewing experience.
As part of its initiative to make moviegoing accessible to all, Mukta A2 Cinemas continues to champion the innovative capped
movie pricing strategy
for both tickets and F&B offerings. The new property will also have the Rs99- cap on Food & Beverages at the premises. This bold move has been transforming the movie business by significantly increasing footfalls and encouraging audiences to return to theaters, even amidst changing entertainment habits.
Satwik Lele, CEO of Mukta A2 Cinemas, said, “We are incredibly excited to bring our latest cinema to Kalyan, marking another important step in our strategic expansion. We believe that high-quality cinema should be accessible to everyone, and our pricing strategy is a testament to this commitment. Our goal is to continue expanding across India and bring Mukta A2 Cinemas to even more audiences, helping transform the movie business by driving footfalls and rekindling the magic of cinema.”
The opening of the Kalyan property is just one of many steps Mukta A2 Cinemas is taking as part of its larger growth strategy. With an eye on further expansion over the next few years, the cinema chain plans to further strengthen its presence across India.

headline: Netflix bets big on India, unveils its biggest content slate for 2025
content:
Netflix
continues to make heavy content investments in India and sees 2025 as its most expansive year in the country as it retains users and grows its subscriber base, said Monika Shergill, vice president of content.
Globally, Netflix has raised its annual content budget for 2025 to $18 billion from $17 billion, with co-CEO Ted Sarandos recently stating that the platform will offer its strongest programming lineup since it began producing original content.
Shergill, who has led Netflix India’s content strategy since 2019, outlined plans to expand original programming and film acquisitions.
The 2025 lineup includes 28 titles across Hindi and South originals, romantic comedies, crime and action, and returning seasons of major franchises. Outside the original programming, the slate also includes theatrical blockbusters like Pushpa 2.
"We are not changing our investment levels at all. In fact, we are doing several big things at a tentpole level," Shergill said in an interview, acknowledging an industry-wide slowdown in
OTT content spending
.

"While there has been an external slowdown, I would say, in the interest of clarity and fairness, that as the market matures and streaming evolves, there is a natural right-sizing of budgets," she noted.
Shergill said 2025 will be Netflix India’s biggest year yet, following a strong 2024 marked by significant growth. She highlighted successful titles such as The Great Indian Kapil Show (two seasons), Heeramandi, Amar Singh Chamkila and IC 814: The Kandahar Hijack, among others.
Its 2025 slate includes high-profile productions like Jewel Thief: The Heist Begins, Akka and Aryan Khan’s Bollywood-themed series, alongside new seasons of The Great Indian Kapil Show, Khakee, Rana Naidu, Kohrra and Delhi Crime.
Netflix, which boasts a 15 million paid base, is also strengthening its south Indian slate with Test, a Tamil cricket drama, and Super Subbu, its first Telugu comedy-drama series. The platform will premiere theatrical films from leading studios such as Ajay Devgn Films, Dharma Productions, Luv Films, Maddock Films, Roy Kapur Films, Salman Khan’s SKF and T-Series.
According to Shergill, Netflix’s diverse content strategy aligns seamlessly with India’s varied audience, catering to different tastes and preferences.
WWE, a long-standing property on Ten Sports and Sony Sports in India, will debut on Netflix with Hindi commentary starting in April. This is part of Netflix’s global $5 billion acquisition of WWE rights, which Shergill hopes will help the platform expand its audience base in India.

headline: FanCode wins MotoGP digital streaming rights in India
content:
FanCode
, India’s digital destination for sports, has strengthened its motorsport portfolio by acquiring the exclusive digital streaming rights for MotoGP. This three-year deal reinforces FanCode’s position as a platform for motorsport fans, building on its success with Formula 1 streaming.
In March 2023, Viacom18, which has since merged with Star India to form Jio Star, secured a media rights deal for exclusive MotoGP live-streaming and broadcasting on
JioCinema
and Sports18 in India, starting with the Grande Premio Tissot de Portugal.
According to FanCode, MotoGP’s popularity in India has risen recently, driven by a growing fan base and the debut of the Indian Grand Prix in 2023, which is set to return. Industry reports show the motorsport audience in India has increased by over 30% in the last five years, with MotoGP becoming a top choice for young fans. The Indian Grand Prix attracted over 1 lakh spectators, highlighting MotoGP's potential in one of the fastest-growing sports markets.
MotoGP’s roster includes top riders like six-time champion Marc Marquez, two-time champion Francesco Bagnaia, 2021 champion Fabio Quartararo, and reigning champion Jorge Martin. Their rivalries and racing have captivated fans worldwide, making each race an event to watch.
Yannick Colaco, Co-Founder of FanCode, said: “MotoGP is one of the most exciting global sporting events, and its growing popularity in India highlights its appeal. With MotoGP’s legacy and future, we are committed to providing an unmatched viewing experience for Indian fans.”

headline: As heroes falter, producers take up the challenge for Bollywood
content:
Mumbai: At a time when confidence to finance fresh films is low and the pool of
film financing
has shrunk, the Hindi film industry is witnessing a gradual increase in
independent film producers
- without the backing of studios - who are collaborating based on their skills and core competencies to make films.
Hansal Mehta, known for films such as Shahid (2012), Citylights (2014) and Aligarh (2015), along with his partner Sahil Saigal, launched a production house -
True Story Films
. This production house has received investments from producers Vinod Bhanushali and Parag Sanghvi. Mantraa Luminosity, a film marketing and distribution company known for releases like Sulemani Keeda (2013) and La La Land (2016) as well as the marketing of Lakshmi (2014) in India, has now diversified into film production. The company launched a production house,
Mayavi Entertainment
, which is aiming to produce at least four films in 2025.
"The industry is going through an incredible shift as it is breaking long-standing patterns. A space is created for new voices to emerge, particularly independent producers who champion a culture of collaboration and teamwork," said Shikha Kapur, founder of Source Global, a content studio.
Echoing a similar sentiment, Rahul Merchant, managing partner of Mayavi Entertainment, said: "Independent producers who are guided by passion and are open for skilful, strategic collaborations are needed more now than ever. We are seeing more independent producers collaborating with each other based on their synergies."
Live Events
Producers seek funding through various routes. These include collaborating with studios, selling rights - digital, music, overseas dubbing and satellite - bank loans (interest rates are as high as 12%) and private financing (two times the bank rates). They also raise funds from long-term private equity investors by offering stakes in their production companies, wealthy individuals and even friends.
After the pandemic, independent producers suffered huge losses as the economics of making Hindi films changed significantly. But in recent years, two favourable developments have provided renewed confidence for them. One is the improving footfalls in theatres, as indicated by the huge success of the Hindi-dubbed Pushpa 2 and the performance of the Sky Force. The other development that these producers consider encouraging is streamers using box office performance as the sole yardstick to buy films.
"The sentiment in the industry is changing. Footfalls in theatres are improving. Recent films have shown reasonably good performance," producer and film business expert Girish Johar said. "These facts have provided confidence to independent producers who are passionate about their stories to collaborate. I see more synergetic collaborations between independent producers."
Sector experts are of the view that increasing collaborations among independent producers will start bearing fruit in terms of new releases in 2026 as films will go on the floors in 2025.
Karmic Films
cofounder and director Suniel Wadhwa said: "This is an era of coexistence. Today, independent producers are no longer solely dependent on traditional studios to greenlight projects. With evolving audience preferences, new funding avenues, and technological advancements, independent producers are driving fresh narratives and innovative business models while still working alongside studios to maximise scale and reach."
Even though the rise of independent producers is reshaping the industry, studios still remain an integral part of the production ecosystem, he added.
A studio makes four to five films a year in Hindi. Some 400-500 Hindi films are produced annually. This shows that there is tremendous potential for independent producers to collaborate and make films.

headline: Number of original series released by streaming platforms in India is at a three-year low
content:
The number of original series released in India by streaming platforms is at a three-year low, shows the data by media and entertainment research and consulting firm
Ormax Media
.
In its recently released research titled
Supply Trends Indian Streaming Originals in 2024
, the media and entertainment research firm observed that between 2021 and 2024, the number of originals (largely in Hindi language) released by streamers fell to 315 in 2024 from 337 in 2021. Interestingly, in the past six years, the number of originals released by streamers peaked in 2023 at 383.
The fall in the releases of originals in India is sharper when one considers the past one year period. Between 2023 and 2024, there has been a drop of 18% in the number of originals released by streamers in India.

Today, an original web series may take a year to make. Then, there are costs and time attached to it. For streamers, it makes sense to selectively buy more films than invest in originals."
At present, it is estimated that there are more than 250 mid-budgets which are already made and yet to secure deals with streamers, point out trade analysts.
The research of Ormax Media notes, "The drop of 18% in supply in 2024 can be attributed to reduction in number of originals on Prime Video, Ullu, Hoichoi, and

The research by Ormax Media takes into account four formats of storytelling produced by streaming platforms in India. These categories are: fiction series, direct-to-OTT films, reality shows, and documentaries.
It has been observed that since 2022, fiction web series has been the dominant format of storytelling. The research observed that 70% of the content produced by streamers was largely fiction web series. In 2024, 214 shows of 315 originals released by streamers were fiction web series. In 2023, of the total originals of 383, the number of fiction web series were 272. This means that between 2023 and 2024, the number of original fiction web series released by streamers in India has declined by 21%.
In terms of content strategies pursued by streamers in India, the Ormax Media research notes that Amazon MX Player, Sony LIV, Disney+ Hotstar, Ullu, and Hungama Play focused largely on fiction series in Hindi. It noted that ZEE5 followed the strategy of releasing the highest number of direct-to-OTT films in India, prioritising the format over web-series. headline: Jio Star secures media rights for International Masters League
content:
JioStar has secured the media rights for the
International Masters League
(IML), a tournament backed by
Sachin Tendulkar
and featuring some of the game’s greatest players. The league’s inaugural season will be broadcast live, with Disney+ Hotstar, Colors Cineplex (SD & HD), and Colors Cineplex Superhits airing all matches from 7:30 PM onwards.
The tournament kicks off on February 22, with an opening clash between India and Sri Lanka. Sachin Tendulkar will lead India, while
Kumar Sangakkara
captains Sri Lanka, reviving historic cricketing rivalries.
"The IML will be a celebration of cricket’s unique and enduring legacy. I can’t wait to step back onto the field with my contemporaries in a league that will be intense and competitive, with all the teams playing hard, but fair," said Sachin Tendulkar, captain of the Indian team.
"The IML is a tribute to cricket’s timeless charm. It is a wonderful opportunity for former cricketers. It's a platform where they can relive old rivalries and reconnect with fans. I am excited to participate in this historic league alongside so many illustrious names," said Kumar Sangakkara, captain of the Sri Lankan team.
Rohan Lavsi, Head – Hindi Movies Business,
Jio Star
, highlighted the tournament’s appeal: “We are delighted to broadcast the inaugural season of the International Masters League on Disney+ Hotstar, along with our linear channels Colors Cineplex and Colors Cineplex Superhits. The IML is more than just a cricket tournament—it is a reunion of greatness. Fans can expect thrilling matches, expert commentary, exclusive behind-the-scenes access, and a lot of nostalgia in the weeks to come.”
Live Events
Jahan Mehta, Director, FSPM, emphasised the partnership: “We are thrilled and honoured to partner with JioStar for the IML. We have no doubt that JioStar, with its experience and expertise in sports broadcasting, will make the league a memorable experience for cricket fans across the globe."

headline: India-Pakistan match is nothing less than a war: Netflix releases 'The Greatest Rivalry' trailer
content:
Streaming platform
Netflix
on Wednesday released the trailer of '
The Greatest Rivalry: India vs Pakistan
', an original documentary series on the cricket rivalry between the two neighbouring counties.
The documentary series, directed by
Chandradev Bhagat
and Stewart Sugg and produced by the Gray Matter Media, will release on Netflix on February 7.
'The Greatest Rivalry' will feature untold stories of the high intensity India vs Pakistan matches narrated by legends including Virender Sehwag, Sourav Ganguly, Sunil Gavaskar, Waqar Younis, Javed Miandad, Ravichandran Ashwin, Inzamam-ul-Haq and Shoaib Akhtar recalling their experiences and unveiling secrets.
"This documentary not only delves into a thrilling saga of sport and history but also fuels the rising excitement to see what chapter unfolds next, making it as relevant today as it is timeless... The series goes beyond the pitch, uncovering the personal stories, cultural undertones, and raw emotions that fuel one of the greatest rivalries in the world," the makers had said in a release.
— NetflixIndia (@NetflixIndia)
Live Events
The promo of the docu-series shows several iconic India vs Pakistan matches, including the 1996 World Cup, 2003 World Cup, 2011 World Cup semi final, the 2007 T20 World Cup final, 2022 T20 World Cup match, the historic 2004-05 series, and the match where Javed Miandad smashed a six off the last ball to win the match.
India vs Pakistan in Champions Trophy
The newest chapter of the rivalry between India and Pakistan will be written on February 23, when the two teams face-off in the
Champions Trophy
at Dubai.
The tournament will be played from February 19 till March 9 and will be hosted by Pakistan and UAE.
Group A of the tournament features current Champions Trophy holders and hosts Pakistan, along with India, New Zealand and Bangladesh, while Group B features Cricket World Cup 2023 champions Australia, alongside Afghanistan, England and South Africa.

headline: Concert economy is boosting tourism, creating jobs: PM Modi
content:
New Delhi:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi
underscored the immense tourism potential in India in new sectors like wedding destinations, natural healing and "
concert economy
" along with spiritual, faith, heritage and pilgrimage sites. With growing curiosity about India in the last decade, there is a thriving market and huge prospects of revenue generation and job creation in these fields in India.
Speaking at the Utkarsh Odisha conclave aimed at promoting Make in India, the prime minister also described eastern India as a growth engine of development with this state playing a key role. Among the avenues of growth in east India are the industrial hubs, ports and trade centres, the prime minister underlined.
"Odisha used to be an important centre in South Eastern Asian trade and the ports were a gateway to India," Modi said, adding that Bali Yatra is celebrated even today in Odisha. Recalling the recent visit of the President of Indonesia to India, the Prime Minister said that the President's words that there were probably traces of Odisha in his DNA. He also mentioned Odisha's connect with South East Asia and the recent visit of President of Singapore to explore ways of promoting the heritage sector.
The ASEAN countries have also shown interest in strengthening trade and traditional connections with Odisha.
India also has great potential in Artificial Intelligence and in industries like food processing, petrochemicals, port-led development, fisheries, IT, edu-tech, textiles, tourism, mining, and green energy, the prime minister said.
Live Events
Modi, who met Punjabi singer Diljit Dosanjh weeks after his highly successful concert with Ed Sheeran, emphasized on the great possibilities in the "concert economy" where numerous avenues of earning money and job creation exist. "With a vast pool of young talent and a massive audience for concerts, India has great possibilities for a thriving concert economy," the prime minister said.
Concert tours of various bands like Coldplay and CAS that have taken place or are scheduled for later this year. While Coldplay performed in Mumbai and Ahmedabad, Dosanjh even held concerts in non-metros like Lucknow.
The rich heritage of India in music, dance, and storytelling, and the large pool of young concert-goers shows the immense possibilities for concert economy, which has seen a spurt in the last decade where the trend and demand for live gigs has grown.
Modi underlined that concerts of Coldplay being held in cities like Ahmedabad is proof of the scope for
live concerts in India
. Prominent global artists are attracted to India today and the concert economy not only boosts tourism but also creates numerous jobs.
The prime minister insisted that the states and private sector should focus on developing the requisite infrastructure and skills for promoting the concert economy. This includes event management, artist grooming, security, and other arrangements, where new opportunities are emerging, he added.
Modi remarked that globally people are curious about India, its heritage and history. The unique attractive aspects are spirituality, the forests, mountains and seas and the impressive ancient temples and architecture.
In Odisha itself, apart from the famous Konark Sun Temple there is a 500-kilometre coastline, over 33% forest cover, and endless possibilities for eco-tourism and adventure tourism. India's focus is on 'Wed in India' and 'Heal in India' and Odisha's natural beauty and environment provide ample backing to these sectors, the prime minister said.
In the national capital, new centres like Bharat Mandapam and Yashobhoomi have become major centres for conference tourism, the prime minister maintained.
Modi remarked that in February, India will host the World Audio Visual and Entertainment Summit (WAVES) for the first time. Emphasising that this important event will display India's creative power to the world, he said such events generate revenue and shape perceptions, thus contributing to the growth of the economy.
WAVES will give a platform to amatuer digital music creators, fashionistas, advertising professionals, designers to showcase their talent.

headline: Madras HC dismisses Netflix' plea against actor Dhanush in copyright infringement issue
content:
The
Madras High Court
on Tuesday dismissed an application filed by Los Gatos, an Indian entity of OTT platform Netflix, which sought to reject actor Dhanush's plaint over alleged copyright infringement by well-known actor
Nayanthara
, her husband Vignesh Sivan and others, at the preliminary stage itself.
Justice Abdul Quddhose
dismissed the application filed by Los Gatos and posted to February 5, further hearing of the application filed by Dhanush's production house Wunderbar, seeking interim injunction against Los Gatos and others.
In his application, Dhanush had submitted he produced a Tamil film "Naanum Rowdy Daan" a few years ago. Some of the behind-the-scene footage from the film were used unauthorizedly in the making of Nayanthara's documentary "Nayanthara: Beyond the Fairytale", he alleged. The documentary was aired on Netflix.
Dhanush said that since Netflix's office was in Mumbai, which was outside the jurisdiction of the Madras HC, he had moved an application seeking leave to sue the OTT player in this court, which was allowed. Aggrieved, Netflix filed the present application to revoke the order, granting leave to sue.
Netflix contended that the plaintiff in this case had obtained leave to sue only Los Gatos and because the office was situated outside the jurisdiction of this court. The plaintiff ought to have obtained leave against all the defendants, Netflix added.
Applications filed by Netflix seeking revocation of leave and rejection of plaint was dismissed by the High Court.

headline: Pushpa 2 OTT release: 5 key facts to know before Allu Arjun-Rashmika Mandanna's film hits Netflix
Disney+ Hotstar’s Coldplay concert live stream hits 83 Lakh views, 16.5 crore watch minutes
content:
Disney+ Hotstar’s live stream of Coldplay’s Music of the Spheres World Tour concert in Ahmedabad garnered 83 lakh views and 16.5 crore minutes of watch time, the platform said in a statement.
It added that fans from across the country tuned in, with Maharashtra, Gujarat, Karnataka, NCR Delhi, Uttar Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, and West Bengal contributing to 85% of the viewership.
Streaming live from Ahmedabad on 26 January 2025, Coldplay’s performance marked a key moment in India’s music and entertainment landscape.
The concert was brought to life through Disney+ Hotstar’s advanced streaming capabilities and immersive audio quality with Dolby 5.1.
Commenting on the success, Sanjog Gupta, CEO-Sports at JioStar, said, “At Disney+ Hotstar, we specialise in delivering compelling and immersive coverage of large-scale live events. We're continually striving to serve elevated experiences combining our strength in storytelling with the power of shared emotional connections. Coldplay Live is a perfect example of how we bring live entertainment and the power of unmissable, shared moments to millions across India.”
Live Events
On achieving another feat, Kiran Mani, CEO-Digital at JioStar, said, “At Disney+ Hotstar, curating live-streaming experiences goes beyond business. Our unparalleled reach driven by our vision to empower audiences makes it imperative for us to deliver premium high-value entertainment experiences for our users. The response to Coldplay’s Music of the Spheres live stream is a testament to our commitment to democratising access to premium experiences, breaking barriers, and redefining how India is entertained.”
He further added, “This is just the beginning of an era where technology and storytelling come together to unlock possibilities in live entertainment.”
Disney+ Hotstar rolled out a marketing campaign targeting Coldplay fans and first-time users, inviting them to experience the live performance. The campaign witnessed promotions with a cross-channel plan, watch parties, and on-platform interactivity.
On-platform interactivity, including Coldplay lyrics integration, allowed fans to engage with the performance in real-time; influencers joined the bandwagon as they rallied their following and hosted watch parties, fostering a community viewing experience. Campaign integrations and placements across BookMyShow, Swiggy, Spotify, YouTube, and other platforms were part of the outreach, targeting communication with those who did not secure tickets.
The #ColdplayOnDisneyHotstar hashtag was trending across social media platforms as fans expressed their excitement, moments, and highlights from the night.
Disney+ Hotstar leveraged streaming features and a pre-live segment to create an interactive experience for viewers. The livestream offered a platform to reach audiences at scale. With Jameson Ginger Ale as the Co-Powered By sponsor, Cisco as the Livestream Event Partner, and Courtyard by Marriott as the Livestream Associate Sponsor, brands partnered with Disney+ Hotstar to create experiences for subscribers, solidifying the platform’s position as the choice for premium visibility.

headline: Bollywood stars who became directors: Kangana, Madhavan & more
Didn't get a chance to attend Coldplay? Here's when and how you can enjoy live streaming of the band's final concert in India at home
content:
Coldplay
fans in India have an exciting opportunity to experience the band’s highly-anticipated concert without needing a ticket.
The iconic British rock band is set to stream their live performance from Ahmedabad straight to your screens on Disney+ Hotstar.
This collaboration between Coldplay and Disney+ Hotstar offers a unique opportunity for fans to enjoy the band’s iconic live performances, marking a first-of-a-kind experience. Expect to sing along to beloved hits such as “Fix You,” “Paradise,” and “Yellow” as Coldplay delivers their signature energy and emotional depth.
When and where to watch
Mark your calendars for tonight, January 26, as the concert kicks off at 7:45 PM IST. Fans can tune in to the live stream on Disney+ Hotstar, broadcasting from the renowned Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad. This is a perfect chance for fans to enjoy the electrifying experience of a Coldplay concert from the comfort of their own homes.
Coldplay's heartfelt message to fans
To share this thrilling news, Coldplay released a heartfelt message directed at their Indian audience. In a special video, band members expressed their excitement saying, “Namaste to all our friends in India! We're so happy to tell you that on January 26, our show from Ahmedabad will be streaming live on Disney+ Hotstar. You can watch it from wherever you are in India!”
Live Events
Preparations in Ahmedabad
The Ahmedabad leg of Coldplay’s Music of the Spheres World Tour is generating immense excitement as the band prepares to take the stage. To ensure a secure and smooth experience for concert-goers, the Gujarat Police have put in place a comprehensive security strategy, deploying over 3,800 personnel, including bomb squad and crime branch officers.
Advanced security measures, such as metal detectors, 400 CCTV cameras, and barricades, have been established to maintain order at the event. Additionally, plainclothes officers, including female staff, will be on patrol to enhance crowd safety.
Joint Commissioner of Police Neeraj Kumar Badgujar highlighted the meticulous planning involved, emphasizing thorough checks at entry points and detailed security protocols.
Coldplay frontman
Chris Martin
and his bandmates kicked off their India tour with a spectacular performance in Mumbai last weekend. During his time there, Martin took the opportunity to explore the city, enjoying leisurely strolls with his girlfriend, actress Dakota Johnson.

headline: A giant is waking: A plethora of problems persists even as intelligent Bengali cinema is starting to break its decades-long shackles
content:
The opening scene of
Anirban Bhattacharya
’s 2021 streaming series, Mandaar, sears itself in the viewer’s mind.
A drone shot tracks a dirt road leading up to a milestone identifying the location – Geilpur, a coastal fishing town in West Bengal. The next shot shows a fish flopping on the beach while a figure in the background seems to mimic the fish’s contortions, heralding this visually striking adaptation of Shakespeare’s Macbeth. It also sets the stage for a depiction of contemporary thuggery and violence in non-bhadralok Bengal, outside the bubble of Kolkata.
Kaushik Ganguly’s 2019 film, Nagarkirtan (Town Song) delves into the complex and complicated relationship that exists between gender and class. Exploring a transgender’s way of navigating a world that is neither urban nor urbane, Riddhi Sen as the protagonist puts up a sterling, nuanced performance that is brilliant in its subtlety.
Debaloy Bhattacharya’s 2024 film Shri Swapankumarer Badami Hyenar Kobole (Sri Swapan Kumar in the Grasp of the Brown Hyena) is a biting satire that not only upturns the ludicrousness of the Bengali action film genre, but also is a homage-cum-ironic take of the grand pulp fiction legacy of bestselling Bengali writer Swapankumar a.k.a. Samarendranath Pandey.
Bengali cinema
, written off for the last 30-odd years as being in terminal decline since the heydays of the trinity of Satyajit Ray-Ritwik Ghatak-Mrinal Sen, seems to be rearing its intelligent, sharp head to be taken note of. It is doing so at a time when cinema-goers have thinned out, preferring the comfort and non-hassle of the remote control at home.
Live Events
Films such Nandita Roy and Shiboprosad Mukherjee’s 2024 heist movie Bohurupi (Chameleon) and Soojit Rino Dutta’s 2024 action thriller Khadaan have been blockbusters, the latter becoming the fastest Bengali film to cross the Rs 5 crore mark in 5 days.
Quality Bengali films, in the minority even in its heydays in the 1960s-70s, punched above its weight. But even that critical mass was drowned out by terribly produced, formulaic films that producers put their money in for quick box office returns.
With the latter drying out – because of cinemas in money-strapped Bengal closing down as well as Hindi films upping their production quality and popularity among the ticket-buying masses – Bengali cinema’s reputation died a slow rear stall death.
But with OTT, the splutter of intelligent popular films – like the 2012 Bhooter Bhobishyot (Future of the Past, or Future of the Ghost), a trenchant comedy that showcases Kolkata living off its past and gives it a rip-roarious shake – is once again attaining a critical mass.
It may not yet be discernible outside the Bengaliphonic sphere, but within the Bengali cinema-watching and streaming show audience, people are sitting up.
Breaking Out
The return of good
Bengali movies
is despite the trying cinema ecosystem, not because it has had a change of direction.
Apart from Srijit Mukherji -- who is now the reigning name in middle-brow Bengali cinema, as well as director of crossover Hindi films like the 2017 Vidya Balan-starring Begum Jaan (a remake of his Bengali film Rajkahini) and co-director with Rohan Sippy of a desi take on Sherlock Holmes, the 2024 TV series starring Kay Kay Menon, Shekhar Home – Bengali cinema still languishes in the ‘glorious past’ for non-Bengali movie followers.
Director-actor Anirban Bhattacharya, explains this paucity, “Bengali audiences are not committed to their own language. It is a result of intellectual downfall in Bengal. It is a socio-political tragedy in every stream of Bengal: theatre, film, poetry, painting and music,” adding, “I am not blaming the audience…. The crisis is more in our own selves.”
“If you ask a person in Bengal about her favourite actor, then she will name Shah Rukh Khan or Ranbir Kapoor first and then a Bengali actor like, say, Parambrata Chattopadhyay and Abir Chatterjee. This is not the case in the south. There, a person will name Faahad Faasil or Allu Arjun first and then a Hindi actor,” he laments.
Southern films of the kind Bhattacharya cites, especially Malayalam and Tamil, have found a huge audience who do not speak or read these languages. That’s because of the ‘sincerity’ and ‘authenticity’ in their vision and storytelling.
Bengali cinema is gaining ground on this front. The story in films is once again becoming important. More energy is being given in writing them. The question is when there will be enough of this kind of cinema for the industry to make a reputational change, especially outside the Bengalisphere.
Shiboprosad Mukherjee, director of critically acclaimed films like the 2013 thriller Alik Shukh (Unreal Happiness) and 2019 Kontho (Voice), says, “A film has to be rooted in its language and culture. That is why Marathi films such as Sairaat and Natsamrat have worked beyond Maharashtra,” adding, “Today we need to make Bengali films with its culture intact.”
Films, like Indranil Roychowdhury’s 2013 Phoring (Dragonfly) on the relationship between a new school teacher and a boy in a town in North Bengal where the main industry has shut down, do mirror contemporary culture and politics.
Aniket Chattopadhyay’s 2019 movie Shankar Mudi (Shankar the Grocer) is a searing tale of how big retail and online shopping affects a kirana owner.
More and more films are depicting ‘reality,’ and importantly, telling stories in an intricate, engaging fashion bearing quality production.
The Search for Ideas
Producers are certainly looking out for more quality writers. Bengali streaming platform Hoichoi throw up a growing number of films and shows – including Mandaar and the other aforementioned films -- that are a visible improvement.
One can argue that this uptick is happening after the malaise was identified and called out. As Anirban Bhattacharya points out, “The Malayalam film industry is experimenting with films such as Bramayugam and Manjummel Boys. But in Bengal, there is no willingness or zeal to experiment with new themes.”
He adds, “there are filmmakers in Bengal who want to do everything with a reference point. They are using references from Mumbai or South Indian films and making movies. Bengali cinema has always been about ideas. If you want to explore an idea, you don't need a big budget for it. It is impossible to convince people that small ideas still can be as penetrating as big films.”
Market Matters
Cultural, creative and – perhaps, above all -- financial challenges exist. Lack of interest of streaming platforms like Netflix and Amazon Prime Video in Bengali films – perhaps emanating from the fact that a dedicated Bengali platform, Hoichoi, monopolises the content, economics of filmmaking, film exhibition and infrastructure – may be hobbling the industry.
Mahendra Soni, co-founder, SVF Entertainment, a leading production house and distributor in Kolkata, explains, “If I know about the existence of a film, then probably I will watch it. Some great films are being made every year in Bengal. They are not the talking points because there is no discovery of these films on international streaming platforms.”
Soni is also co-founder of Hoichoi. “Today, a large number of southern films are mostly discovered through these international streaming platforms. But these platforms are not picking Bengali films because they have not built this category on their platforms thoroughly.”
The limited reach of Bengali films is a chicken-and-egg conundrum: people are not betting on good Bengali films because they don’t know of their existence, while there is a shortage of good Bengali content because nobody is putting their money there.
Director Arin Paul, who made the 2008 comedy 10:10, points out, “In the South, a film is simultaneously released in more than two states apart from the home state. So, there are multiple markets to make good money. In Bengal, makers are largely dependent on the state itself for revenues. Even the budget of promoting Bengali films is very small.”
More than 80% of Bengali films are made within a budget of Rs 2 crore. Only films which boast of big names can have budgets of Rs 5-7 crore. But the additional cost of promotion -- between Rs 75 lakh and Rs 1.5 crore -- is pretty much that of making the film. As a result, films are hardly marketed after their release with no one outside West Bengal, even among the Bengali diaspora, getting to know about them.
This is something that OTT platforms like Hoichoi have started to rectify, especially since West Bengal has only 24 multiplexes -- Maharashtra has 200. Paucity of halls obviously have a bearing on box office receipts. West Bengal contributes only 7-8% of the total box office of Indian films.
Bengali film watchers are coming out of that moan-zone of ‘Oh, for the good old days’ as they are treated to better-made, better-told, better-shown movies and shows.
Your turn, rest of the world.

headline: Tata Sons seeks CCI clearance to acquire additional 10 pc stake in Tata Play
content:
Tata Sons, promoter of Tata Group, has sought approval from fair trade regulator CCI for acquiring an additional 10 per cent stake in DTH operator
Tata Play
from Singapore's sovereign wealth fund
Temasek Holdings
. Currently, Tata Sons owns a 60 per cent stake in Tata Play. After the completion of the deal, Tata Sons will have a 70 per cent holding in the entertainment content distribution platform.
Tata Sons Pvt Ltd is an investment holding company, which is registered as a core investment company with the Reserve Bank of India and classified as a "Systemically Important Non-Deposit Taking Core Investment Company".
"The proposed transaction relates to Tata Sons' acquisition of 10 per cent shareholding in Tata Play from Baytree Investments (Mauritius) Pte Ltd," said a notice filed with the Competition Commission of India (CCI) on Thursday.
Baytree Investments (Mauritius) is an affiliate of Singapore's sovereign wealth fund Temasek Holdings.
The proposed transaction is being notified to the Commission under Section 6(2) and Section 5(a) of the Competition Act, 2002, Tata Sons said.

Section 6(2) of the Competition Act pertains to any person or enterprise to notify the CCI before entering into a combination, while Section 5(a) defines a combination as the acquisition of one or more enterprises, or the merger or amalgamation of enterprises that exceed a certain threshold.

Accordingly, the definition of the relevant market may remain open, the CCI may assess the transaction in the context of wired broadband internet services in India and the complementary link between internet access provided by Tata Sons through its affiliates and web-based services like Tata Play Binge, it added.

headline: 5 OTT releases this week: Hisaab Barabar, Sweet Dreams & more
ZEEL files $8 million counterclaim against Star India in ICC TV rights dispute
content:
Zee Entertainment Enterprises Limited
(
ZEEL
) has filed a counterclaim of $8 million, plus interest, against
Reliance Industries
Limited (RIL)-backed
Star India
. This follows Star's $940 million damages claim over the failed International Cricket Council (ICC) contract, which is currently under arbitration at the London Court of International Arbitration (LCIA).
The counterclaim pertains to the Rs 69 crore that ZEEL had paid to Star under the terms of the agreement.
In a regulatory filing, ZEEL stated that arbitration is at an early stage, with the LCIA yet to determine ZEEL’s alleged liability for breaches of the Alliance Agreement with Star.
ZEEL submitted its statement of defence on 23 December 2024, refuting all claims made by Star. A three-member arbitral tribunal has been constituted by the LCIA to oversee the dispute. On 16 September 2024, Star filed its statement of case, including an expert report on damages and a witness statement.
The dispute arises from the Alliance Agreement signed on 26 August 2022, under which Star agreed to sub-license TV broadcasting rights for ICC men’s cricket events from 2024 to 2027 to ZEEL.
Live Events
Star, then wholly owned by Walt Disney, took over the
ICC media rights
valued at $3 billion after ZEEL withdrew from the agreement. Now majority owned by RIL, with
Walt Disney
and Bodhi Tree Systems as other shareholders, Star claims ZEEL failed to pay the first instalment of $203.56 million (Rs 1,693 crore) and cited additional obligations totalling Rs 17 crore for bank guarantee commission and deposit interest.
Star initiated arbitration proceedings in March 2024, seeking enforcement of the agreement or damages. In June 2024, Star terminated the agreement and focused solely on claiming damages. ZEEL, in turn, sought a refund of Rs 69 crore, arguing the agreement had become void due to Star’s failure to meet its obligations.
ZEEL said it is confident that the dispute will not significantly impact its operations or finances, citing the strength of its legal position.
The company's board continues to monitor the matter and believes the company has strong and valid grounds to defend any claims by Star, it added.
Previously, ZEEL had argued that the ICC agreement could not proceed due to unfulfilled conditions precedent, including financial commitments, guarantees, and ICC approval for the sub-licensing arrangement.
The ICC agreement was also impacted by ZEEL’s planned merger with
Sony Pictures Networks India
, which eventually fell through.
Star India, meanwhile, reported a standalone net loss of Rs 12,548 crore for the financial year ending 31 March 2024, primarily due to a Rs 12,319 crore provision for an "onerous contract" related to the ICC media rights deal, according to a regulatory filing.

headline: Nielsen earns Media Rating Council accreditation for Big Data + Panel National TV measurement
content:
The Media Rating Council (MRC) has completed its accreditation process for Nielsen's innovative Big Data + Panel
National TV measurement
. This follows the recent accreditation of Nielsen's integration of first-party live streaming data and the re-accreditation of its traditional Panel measurement. With this, Nielsen becomes the first accredited national
TV audience measurement
provider for Big Data + Panel.
“The accreditation of Nielsen’s Big Data + Panel is a landmark moment for TV ratings, as it will forever change audience measurement,” said Karthik Rao, Nielsen CEO. “No one else pairs a high-quality, representative panel with a data set this large, pulling from smart TVs and set-top boxes in more than 45 million homes. I believe Big Data + Panel gives the industry the most accurate measurement in the history of TV. We’re grateful to our clients for helping us innovate once again.”
George Ivie, CEO and Executive Director of the MRC, remarked, “MRC has completed and evaluated rigorous audits of Nielsen’s National Service and its new components, including first-party streaming (thus far consisting of select NFL games) and the integration of big data. We have now approved the integration of big data so this combined methodology can be considered MRC accredited. This effort marks the first time MRC has accredited a hybrid panel/big-data product inclusive of persons-level estimates.”
“The NFL continues to support Nielsen’s efforts to modernise measurement so we can all benefit from accurate insights in an increasingly fragmented media marketplace,” said Paul Ballew, Chief Data & Analytic Officer of the NFL. “The accreditation of their Big Data solution is a significant step in the journey, and we commend Nielsen for their efforts.”
Big Data + Panel National TV Measurement combines Nielsen’s high-quality, representative panel data with insights from cable and satellite set-top boxes and smart TVs across 45 million households and 75 million devices. This measurement fuels planning and cross-platform audience analysis in both Nielsen’s ecosystem and its partners’ systems.
Live Events
Beyond advertising, the solution supports content programming, licensing decisions, and TV distribution agreements. It was widely adopted by broadcasters and agencies for the 2024 Upfront season, with Nielsen endorsing its use as currency heading into 2025.
In addition to Big Data + Panel, Nielsen has expanded National TV out-of-home measurement, which is under review by the MRC. Nielsen also leads in streaming measurement with products like Streaming Content Ratings, powering Nielsen’s Streaming Top 10, and Streaming Platform Ratings, which inform The Gauge and Media Distributor Gauge.
For advertisers and agencies, Nielsen has expanded Nielsen ONE to include outcomes capabilities alongside advanced audiences, planning, and measurement tools. While Nielsen ONE is not currently submitted to MRC for accreditation, plans for evaluation are underway.

headline: Ayushmann Khurrana named brand ambassador for FICCI Frames' 25th anniversary
content:
FICCI Frames
, India’s global
media and entertainment
convention, is set to celebrate its
25th anniversary
this year, and Bollywood star
Ayushmann Khurrana
has been unveiled as the event's
brand ambassador
.
The silver jubilee edition of FICCI Frames will spotlight the theme “RISE: Redefining
Innovation
, Sustainability, and Excellence.” This theme underscores the event’s focus on shaping narratives, fostering creativity, and driving change within the media and entertainment landscape.
Ayushmann Khurrana expressed his excitement, stating, “It is a huge honor for me to be announced as the first Brand Ambassador for FICCI Frames in its silver jubilee year! As someone who came to Mumbai with just dreams in my eyes, I’m deeply humbled to represent an industry that has given me so much. I look forward to championing disruption, celebrating innovation, and showcasing the excellence that defines Indian entertainment."
FICCI Frames has evolved into a platform that unites industry leaders, creative professionals, and policymakers from around the globe. Held annually in Mumbai, the convention features keynote addresses, policy roundtables, masterclasses, B2B meetings, and cultural events. It also hosts the
Best Animated FRAMES Awards
(BAF) and a global content market.
Over the years, the event has attracted personalities, including Hollywood actor Hugh Jackman, former FCC Commissioner Ajit Pai, Mukesh Ambani, and Bollywood stars such as
Amitabh Bachchan
and Shahrukh Khan.
Live Events
Kevin Vaz, Chair of the
FICCI Media and Entertainment Committee
, said, “Ayushmann embodies the creativity, innovation, and excellence that FICCI Frames stands for. His journey resonates with the ethos of this event, and his association will inspire future generations of storytellers and creators.”
The 25th edition of FICCI Frames will focus on technologies like
artificial intelligence
, virtual reality, and the metaverse, alongside traditional media and entertainment. The event promises to be a celebration of India’s storytelling while paving the way for advancements.
The FICCI Media and Entertainment Committee is led by Kevin Vaz and co-chaired by Sandhya Devanathan (VP and MD, Meta India) and Arjun Nohwar (GM, South Asia, Warner Bros. Discovery).
